intro: Sairocarpus cornutus subsp. leptaleus, commonly known as the slender-fruited sandverbena, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Verbenaceae family and is characterized by its compact growth habit and hairy stems. The plant produces small, tubular flowers that are typically pink to purple in color, often arranged in clusters at the ends of the branches. It thrives in sandy or gravelly soils and is often found in open, sunny habitats such as coastal dunes and disturbed areas. Its botanical features make it an important component of local ecosystems, supporting various pollinators and contributing to biodiversity.
